data.text: Introduction
1.1. Electronic mail (E-mail) is designed to complement other methods of communication rather than totally replacing the need for face-to-face or telephone communication.
1.2. Corporate email services are provided to serve operational and administrative purposes in connection with the Trust's business.

1.3. Use of the Trust based and/or NHS Mail e-mail systems by employees of the Mid Essex, Basildon or Southend Trusts is permitted and encouraged where such use supports the objectives and goals of the business.

1.4. It is important to define what is and is not acceptable when using the e-mail system and how unacceptable use will be dealt with; it is therefore expected that staff will conduct themselves in an honest and appropriate manner when using e- mail facilities and in particular must not:
Place at risk the integrity, security or operation of Trust IT systems or equipment;
Engage in any action or activity, which would place themselves as individuals or the Trust, liable to criminal prosecution or civil action;
Create any unauthorised contractual liability on the part of the Trust;
Intentionally access or disseminate any inappropriate material;
Create or disseminate any offensive material, including but not limited to, material of a sectarian, racist, sexually explicit, discriminatory or defamatory nature;
Engage in any action, which would bring the Trust into disrepute;
Contravene current legislation;
Create any unnecessary business risk to the Trust by misuse of E-mail or the internet.
1.5. All emails processed by the corporate IT systems and networks are considered to be the organisation's property which contribute to the Trust's “corporate memory.
1.6. Email is not inherently secure, particularly outside the Trust's own internal network. Messages can be intercepted, stored, read, modified and forwarded to anyone, and sometimes go missing.
1.7. Emails may be requested to be provided under the Freedom of Information Act or as a result of Subject Access Requests under the Data Protection Act.
Scope
2.1. This policy defines how email, encompassing other forms of electronic text based communication such as instant messaging solutions etc., are used in the conduct of Trust business.
2.2. The terms of this policy applies to all Trust based and/or NHSMail e-mail systems which encompass other forms of electronic text based communication such as instant messaging solutions etc.

2.3. IT systems are rapidly evolving and it is conceivable that additional text based communications may be implemented following the commencement of this policy; whilst these may not be explicitly identified, it is expected that this policy will apply in totality to these also.
2.4. It applies to all users who have been granted access to Trust IT computer systems and encompasses access, or attempted access, to approved Webmail systems including NHSMail.
2.5. The purpose of this document is to:
Set out who may legitimately use the Trust's e-mail system
Set out the general rules for the use of the Trust E-mail system
Ensure that users protect the confidentiality and security of information
To provide guidance on e-mail conduct to minimise the risk of E-mails being perceived as threatening
Minimise the risk of litigation resulting from inappropriate use, in which the Trust may be vicariously liable for the acts of its employees
Ensure E-mail users adopt best practice
Definitions and Terminology

table_items.text: This should be in reference to the individual Trust that the employee is employed by. Trusts refereed to include Mid Essex Hospital NHS Trust, Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, and Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust.
This refers to the Mid Essex, Southend & Basildon Trusts as they are starting to come together to form a Group model of service delivery. Also sometimes referred to as the MSB Group.
A consumer orientated mobile device that maybe either the personal property of a member of staff, or Trust issued to meet a specific business need.

Throughout this document the term e-mail is taken to include any form of electronic text based communication used in the conduct of Trust business e.g. instant messaging solutions, approved Webmail systems etc.

Person Identifiable Information / Person Identifiable Data / Personal Confidential Data. One or more pieces of information that relate to an individual, who can be identified from those pieces of information or identified by combining those pieces of information with other information that is likely to be available. The individuals concerned may be patients, staff, contractors or members of the public.

Vicarious liability is a form of secondary liability where a person or organisation is liable for the acts of another. An employer can be legally responsible for the actions or omissions of their employees in the course of their employment. The employer is legally responsible unless it can be shown that 'reasonable steps' have been made to reduce this liability.

Sectarianism is bigotry, discrimination or hatred arising from attaching importance to perceived differences between subdivisions within a group, such as between different denominations of a religion or the factions of a political movement and is characterised by prejudice against other beliefs.
Libellous or slanderous statements that cause injury to another person, harms their personal or professional
reputation or causes others to shun or avoid them.
Any product of someone's intellect that has commercial value, especially copyrighted material, patents, and trademarks.
Outlook Web Access – a means of accessing the Trust E-mail system from the Internet remotely (i.e. not on Trust premises and not the computer network)
A Microsoft technology enabling Exchange email to be configured on a mobile device using the native device email client.
Either bespoke approved NHS systems e.g. NHSMail or approved for NHS Trust use through award of Cabinet Office G-Cloud Impact Level (IL2) accreditation.

data.text: Roles & Responsibilities
Role & Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees)
4.1.1. Digital  Services  Governance  Group  –  to  review  policies  and  recommend submission for group approval.
4.1.2. Information Governance Committee – to review any instances of non-compliance to stated policy.
4.1.3. Joint Document Management Group – to ratify polices
4.2.  Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust
4.2.1. Senior Information Risk Officer (SIRO) – Joint Executive Group (JEG) appointed Chief Information Officer responsible for ensuring:
Serious information risk management issues are brought to the Board for decision as required.
A lead or manager is in place to organise and enforce the Group's approach to information risk management.

Written advice is provided to the Accountable Officer and appropriate Trust Boards  regarding  the  information  risk  management  content  of  the  annual report and Statement of Internal Control (SIC).
4.2.2. Caldicott Guardian – Board appointed Site Director for each Trust is responsible for:
Protecting the confidentiality of PCD processed by the Trust, ensuring that all sites satisfy the highest practical standards for handling PCD.
Acting as the “conscience” of the Trust, by actively supporting work to enable use and sharing of PCD where this is appropriate and advising on lawful and ethical solutions.
Championing confidentiality and information sharing requirements and issues at Board level and, where appropriate, at a range of levels within the Trust's overall governance framework.
4.2.3. Head of Digital Services, MSB Group
Operational responsibility for development and updating of Digital Services Policies.
4.2.4. Head of Information Governance, MSB Group
Operational responsibility for information governance.
4.2.5. Line Managers
Responsible for ensuring that staff are aware of this policy that they adhere to it and for managing issues which arise when staff fail to comply.
4.2.6. Trust Staff
Responsible for implementing and complying with the policy within the areas of their responsibility or control.
Policy Requirements
5.1. Authorised Users
5.1.1. Access will not be granted to the Trust E-mail systems until satisfactory completion of access request process in accordance with the Access Control Policy.
5.1.2. Departmental managers must approve access for external contractors using the same access request process as for permanent staff.

5.1.3. It is a condition of use of IT and E-mail facilities provided by the Trust that the user agrees to be bound by the relevant policies and regulations as detailed in the access request documentation.
5.2. Access to E-mail

5.2.1. The Trust's E-mail functionality is provided by the Microsoft Exchange and Outlook client software. This is the only permitted software to be used to access the Exchange servers; any other E-mail client software must not be configured to access these systems.

5.2.2. The only other authorised method for accessing E-mail remotely from elsewhere on the internet is via the connect gateway that allows authorised users to check E-mail and calendars using the Outlook Web Access (OWA) solution that is provided to permit access through an internet browser over a secure (SSL) connection or via pre-authorised mobile device using Microsoft Exchange Active Sync. This requires additional licensing so is only available on a user by user basis following a request via the IT Self Service Portal.
5.2.3. The E-mail systems, and information contained within, are owned by the Trust.

5.2.4. The Trust reserves the right to monitor and access any E-mail messages; this may be as part of routine maintenance and management of the E-mail system or when required for Information Governance or HR investigations.

5.2.5. Whilst the use of E-mail for incidental and occasional personal purposes is permitted, it should not be used for private confidential correspondence as confidentiality cannot be assured. Such use must not directly or indirectly interfere with the Trust's systems or burden the Trust with any additional costs. The use of Trust computer resources is subject to English law and any abuse will be dealt with appropriately.
5.2.6. Staff may not use Gmail, Hotmail, Yahoo or similar external / third-party email services (commonly known as “webmail”) unless explicitly approved by the IT department.
5.2.7. Staff will not be permitted to access their emails after they have left the organisation, nor will permission be granted to allow access to their mail box either on site or remotely.
5.3. Use of E-mail
5.3.1. All users are responsible for ensuring that their E-mail usage complies with this policy and that it is ethical and lawful.
5.3.2. The sending of text or images that contain material of an offensive, indecent or obscene nature is prohibited unless it pertains to normal Trust business.

5.3.3. Provided the appropriate security guidelines are followed, E-mails sent from one Trust user to another on the Trust E-mail system are relatively secure, any E- mails to external email addresses, unless they are encrypted.
5.3.4. Users must not commit the organisation to a third party for example through purchase or sales contracts, job offers or price quotations, unless explicitly authorised by management to do so.

5.3.5. Users may delegate rights to other E-mail users from within Microsoft Outlook, but under no circumstances must they share login credentials. This will allow other users to have different levels of access to their mail, calendars etc. It is at their discretion to whom they give access but they take full responsibility for those user actions. Additionally they should automatically provide access to their line manager and above if requested.
5.3.6. Users must not interfere with or remove the standard corporate email disclaimer automatically appended to outbound emails.
5.3.7. E-mail may be used for any legal activity in continuation of the aims or policies of the Trust, subject to the conditions listed below. The following specific uses are excluded:
Any use that violates Trust policies or standards
Any use that brings the Trust into disrepute;
The transmission of E-mails with or without attachments that are known to contain viruses or other harmful software;
The use of another individual's E-mail account by using that individual's identity (i.e. the individual's username/password details);
The use of E-mail that could result in the inadvertent commitment of the Trust to a contract or agreement if it appears to the other party that the e- mail user has authority to do so;
The creation of anonymous messages. All E-mails must be attributable to a named sender;
Impersonation or misrepresentation of another individual;
Alterations of source or destination address information;

The use of external E-mail accounts (e.g. Hotmail, Gmail) for Trust purposes is not permitted: this is to ensure data security, sender authorisation and data protection issues. This includes auto-forwarding of Trust E-mail to external accounts;
The use of E-mail to promote or denigrate companies or organisations, or defame other employees;

The use of bulk E-mails, including excessive use of mailing lists, which is unrelated to the legitimate business activities of the Trust and is likely to cause offence or inconvenience to those receiving it;
Sending copies of documents in breach of copyright laws;
The use of E-mail to harass or intimidate others or to interfere with the ability of others to conduct Trust business.
5.4. E-mails containing PII/PID/PC
5.4.1. E-mails containing PII/PID/PCD sent to external recipients from the Trust E-mail system will be automatically blocked/quarantined where such technologies are in place.
5.4.2. Users requiring support to be able to send PII/PID/PCD information externally via the Trust Secure Messaging solution should contact the IT Self-service Desk.

5.4.3. The Trust has a secure encrypted E-mail mechanism in place for the sending of such E-mails that ensures that the public network (internet) transport of information cannot be intercepted and decoded thereby maintaining the integrity and confidentiality of the information.
5.4.4. Email users are not permitted to circumvent such measures to protect data and may be subject to the Trust's Disciplinary Policy if attempted.
5.5. Web-based E-mail accounts

5.5.1. The Trust's policy on the use of web-based E-mail accounts such as Hotmail, Gmail, or ISP equivalent is that they are not permitted. This is fully in accordance with mandatory Information Governance guidelines and Connecting for Health best practice instructions.
5.5.2. Access is permitted to bespoke NHS systems e.g. NHSMail  or systems approved for NHS Trust use through award of Cabinet Office G-Cloud Impact Level (IL2) accreditation.
5.5.3. For information regarding social networking sites, blogs etc., please refer to the relevant Acceptable Use of IT and Internet Policies.
5.6. Mobile Device Connections

5.6.1. The Trust will apply security requirements on mobile devices whether they are Trust owned or “personal” devices, connected to its infrastructure. As phone technology becomes more advanced, it has become necessary for the Trust to treat them just as any other computer connected to Trust resources. This change will allow the Trust to better protect access to resources such as email, contact and calendar information, but it will also help protect the user's phone, text messaging and other information from abuse by unknown and unauthorized persons.

5.6.2. The security requirements will be applied to any mobile device connecting to OWA, at Mid Essex Trust this includes remote  wiping of the device after 8 incorrect attempts. This is irrespective of whether it is Trust or personal data.

5.6.3. If staff lose their mobile device and it is connected to the Trust email system, staff should contact the IT Helpdesk immediately. The Trust has the ability to initiate a "remote wipe" which will erase all data on the phone.

5.6.4. Once this policy is applied, staff will no longer be able to receive email, update their calendar or contacts until their device has met the security requirements. The device should prompt staff that it is out of compliance and return the device to security settings. Once requirements are met, the device will function again, as normal.
5.6.5. If the password for the device is lost, the Trust will not be able to recover it.
5.7. Personal use of Trust E-mail Facilities

5.7.1. Limited personal use of the corporate email systems is permitted at the discretion of local management; it should be kept to the bare minimum and not used excessively or interfere with Trust business.

5.7.2. The forwarding of inappropriate E-mails such as ones containing jokes, videos, pictures, round robin and other unnecessary types of communication are not permitted; this places an unnecessary extra burden on the Trust IT infrastructure and is contrary to any job requirement.

5.7.3. Staff may have no expectations of privacy: all emails traversing the corporate systems and networks are subject to automated scanning and may be quarantined and / or reviewed by authorised employees.
5.7.4. All emails processed by the corporate IT systems and networks are considered to be the organisation's property which contribute to the Trust's “corporate memory”.
5.7.5. Any and all Emails may be requested to be provided by the Trust under the Freedom of Information Act, or as a result of Subject Access Requests under the Data Protection Act.
5.8. Legal Consequences of Misuse of E-mail Facilities
5.8.1. In a growing number of cases involving civil or criminal law, E-mail messages (deleted or otherwise) are produced as evidence in a permanent written form.
5.8.2. There are a number of areas of law which apply to use of E-mail and which could involve liability of users or the Trust which include, but are not limited to, the following:

5.8.3. Intellectual property - anyone who uses E-mail to send or receive any materials that infringe the intellectual property rights of a third party may be liable to that third party if such use is not authorised by them;

5.8.4. Obscenity - it is a criminal offence to publish any material which is pornographic, excessively violent or which comes under the provisions of the Obscene Publications Act 1959. Similarly the Protection of Children Act 1978 makes it an offence to publish or distribute obscene material of a child or children;

5.8.5. Defamation - as a form of publication, the E-mail is within the scope of legislation relating to libel where a statement or opinion is published which adversely affects the reputation of a person, group of people or an organisation. Legal responsibility for the transmission of any defamatory, obscene or rude remarks which discredit an identifiable individual or organisation will rest mainly with the sender of the E-mail and may lead to substantial external financial penalties being imposed.

5.8.6. Data Protection - processing information (including photographs) which contains personal data about individuals requires the express written consent of those individuals. Any use of personal data beyond that registered with the Information Commissioner will be illegal and may be subject to financial penalties to the Trust; where in doubt please refer to the Head of Information Governance, MSB Group
5.8.7. Discrimination - any material disseminated which is discriminatory or encourages discrimination may be unlawful under Equality and Discrimination legislation.
5.9. Breach of Policy
5.9.1.  In addition to the legal liabilities outlined above, staff who breach any of the terms of this policy may be subject to disciplinary action under the appropriate Trust's Disciplinary Policy.
5.10. Obligations of staff and line managers on employment termination

5.10.1. Due to the volume of E-mails received by the Trust's servers, it is not possible to archive all E-mails across all Trusts permanently. Therefore the obligation of the maintenance of important E-mails falls to the employee.
5.10.2. Prior to leaving the organisation staff should forward any important emails to their line manager.

5.10.3. Upon confirmation of the staff last working day at the Trust the staff's email account will be disabled. Trust local processes regarding the retention and continued access will apply; please refer to the IT service desk for further information regarding local processes and timescales.
Training Requirements

6.1. No specific training requirements have been identified however staffs are expected to ensure that they keep up to date regarding IG and IT/Cyber security update emails and messages published in staff circulars.
Monitoring & Audit
7.1. Under UK law, employers may be liable for what the conduct of their employees during the course of their work; this includes employees using E-mail to send defamatory or offensive messages.
7.2. Managers are also expected to ensure that staff are not spending excessive amounts of time using E-mail for personal purposes and that such conduct only occurs during authorised breaks.

7.3. Emails on the corporate IT systems are automatically scanned for malicious software, spam and unencrypted proprietary or personal information. Unfortunately, the scanning process is not 100% effective (e.g. compressed and encrypted attachments may not be fully scanned), therefore undesirable / unsavoury emails are sometimes delivered to users. Delete such emails or report them as security incidents to the IT Helpdesk in the normal way.

7.4. Filtering/virus-scanning can never be 100% effective so any unsolicited E-mails and attachments should always be treated with caution. Similarly, an E-mail may be incorrectly marked as infected or “spam” and become unnecessarily blocked.
7.5. IT reserves the right of access to users' E-mail and audit logs on both the client workstation and the servers for legitimate purposes, such as investigation of complaints of misuse.

7.6. Contents and audit logs for both sent and received E-mail may be inspected (including  personal  E-mail)  at  any  time  with  appropriate  notification  to  the member of staff - Authorisation must be given by an HR representative from the appropriate Trust, the MSB Group Head of Information Governance and/or the MSB Group Head of Digital Services.

7.7. Email can be covertly monitored where the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act   is  invoked  or  the  Telecommunication  (Lawful  Business Practice)(Interception of Communications) Regulations 2000.

7.8. IT will endeavour to maintain privacy of E-mail, however, there may be special cases  where  it is  essential  that  E-mail  messages  are  accessed  due  to,  for example,  illness  of  the  owner  of  a  mailbox.  In  these  instances  written authorisation  must  be  provided by  the  member  of  staff  or  the  departmental manager (if the former is not possible) in conjunction with an IT support call registered on ITSM.

7.9. Certain authorised members of IT may have necessity to access the contents of E-mail messages in the course of system administration; any inappropriate E- mails that are identified will be reported.
7.10. The Trust has a legal duty to report to the police any access to or downloading of illegal material (For example, child pornography).
7.11. IT reserves the right to take special actions in administering E-mail if this is essential to preserve the integrity or functionality of the system. This may include the deletion of E-mail.

Appendix 1: Code of Practice for all E-mail Users

Studies have shown that E-mail can be a source of conflict because, due to its intention of being a short, sharp and to the point method of communication, the normal pleasantries and non-verbal elements are missing.
Users should therefore adhere to the following guidelines for appropriate use:
Check your E-mail regularly in accordance with the requirements of your role.

Users must recognise that certain communications may be time critical. “I didn't check my E-mail”, and errors in forwarding, or other error message are not acceptable excuses for missing official Trust communications sent by E-mail.

Be polite. Messages sent by E-mail can often seem abrupt, even when this is not the intention. Use professional courtesy and discretion. The use of all upper-case text (capitals) in either the subject or the body of an E-mail should also be avoided as this is deemed to be the E-mail equivalent of shouting;
Before you send an E-mail, read it through to make sure it really does say what you want it to say;
Do not say anything in an E-mail that you would not be prepared to say to someone face to face;
Use ‘reply all' and distribution lists with caution in order to keep the number of messages to a minimum and reduce the risk of sending messages to the wrong people;
Staff must set the Out-of-Office option when they are away from the office stating the expected length of their absence and an alternative contact for work-related matters;
Messages should be addressed to those from whom an action or response is expected. “Cc” or “bcc” should be used for other recipients for whom the message is for information only;
Respect peoples' privacy and consider this aspect before forwarding messages;
Delete unwanted or unnecessary E-mail. It is the user's responsibility to manage their E-mail folders and keep within the set mailbox limits. Trust IT can give advice and assistance if required;
Unsolicited E-mail, especially with an attachment, may contain a virus or other harmful software. If in doubt, delete the E-mail or contact the sender to check before opening;
Do not try to carry out confidential or sensitive tasks or express controversial views via E-mail;

Enter a meaningful title in the ‘subject' field at the top of the E-mail to help the reader anticipate the content correctly. Try to keep to one subject per message to help avoiding unnecessary confusion;
Do not use all or part of someone else's message without acknowledgement. Do not edit someone else's message without making it clear what changes you have made;
Do not use a Trust E-mail address to subscribe to non-business related mailing lists (e.g. shopping mailing lists). Unsubscribe from business related mailing lists when they are no longer required;
E-mail transmissions and postings to electronic notice-boards should be limited to matters of Trust business;

E-mail distribution lists should only be used for matters of Trust business. Requests for E-mails to be sent to all users should be correctly formatted and passed to the Communications team for approval.

Do not forward E-mail “chain letters”. These are E-mails which either ask you to forward them on to multiple users and which may state that something bad will happen if you do not forward them. E-mails of this type, which are warning about something (e.g. computer viruses), are almost certainly hoaxes.
Appendix 2: Cautionary Information
The nature of E-mail is such that total confidentiality cannot be guaranteed and users should be aware of the following points about E-mail use:
Copies of E-mail may exist on a back-up copy or a remote system even after the author or recipient has deleted the message;
E-mail may be forwarded by any recipient without the author's consent: it may not have been the author's intention that the mail should be forwarded.
A forwarded message may be a modified version of the original;
It is possible for the author or sender of an E-mail to disguise or alter their identity.

Organisations outside the Trust may have different E-mail policies. Some consider it the property of the organisation, subject to examination, copying or forwarding. Be aware of this possibility when sending E-mail;
A reply to a personal message sent via a ‘listserver' or electronic bulletin board may be inadvertently distributed to all subscribers to the list;

Usernames and passwords must not be disclosed to others. This could result in security breaches and other people using your E-mail account to send unauthorised messages. Suspected security breaches should be reported to Information Governance in accordance with IS02 immediately;
Once a message is sent, there is no definite way to retrieve it. Check carefully that messages are addressed to the correct recipient(s) before sending.
Appendix 3: Malicious Email Awareness
The Trust has sophisticated E-mail filters which prevent about 5,000 malicious E-mails from reaching staff every day.

However there is a constant battle against the senders of these E-mails and sometimes malicious E-mails do get through. Whilst the majority of these E-mails are just spam there is a risk that some of them could contain viruses or spyware so if you receive an E- mail that has any of the following then delete it immediately.
You do not know the sender.
The mail contains spelling errors.
The subject line and content doesn't match.
Makes an offer that seems too good to be true.
Contains an urgent offer end date.
Contains a request to forward the E-mail to multiple people.
Contains attachments that you are not expecting.
If you are unsure then please contact the IT Service Desk.
